headline: Homemade Turkey Breakfast Sausage
description: Homemade turkey breakfast sausage, nicely seasoned with sage, marjoram, and red pepper flakes, is ready in less than 30 minutes.
name: Homemade Turkey Breakfast Sausage

recipeInstructions.text: Mix sage, salt, black pepper, red pepper flakes, and marjoram together in a small bowl. Place turkey in a large bowl and mix the spice mixture into the turkey using your hands; form into patties.

Cook patties in a large skillet over medium-high heat until no longer pink in the center and the juices run clear, about 5 minutes per side. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C).

review.reviewBody: It’s sad when people take a recipe, hack it up, add to it and it becomes a shadow of the intended recipe….SURE I am all for if you hate an ingredient, leave it out but don’t butcher the original recipe by a review bc you didn’t like after you’ve tossed in the kitchen sink!… NO need for disparaging remarks…did I love this, no, it’s just not a recipe I’d repeat but I’ll spare everyone the I added etc etc…I just prefer a more robust, mix of seasonings and a bit of heat…it’s not bad, if you’re inclined to add, experiment….by all means, please do so. Don’t offer a “review” unless it’s for the original recipe… otherwise it’s a review of your own creation…that’s what bugs me, a review of NOT the original…

Great recipe! I adjusted the recipe for 3lbs of turkey. I used rubbed sage and doubled the amount of required sage. I used 1 ts of red pepper flakes (for the 3lbs of turkey). Cooked it all with a little olive oil and refrigerated most of them for quick reheat this week. Might experiment with adding Maple syrup.

This was TOO salty and not enough spices to give it that classic sausage flavor. 1/2 teaspoon of salt per pound is PLENTY. There is another review in here that says ground sage is more potent than dried sage, instructing to use 1/4 the amount. Don't make this mistake when using ground sage or it will seriously lack flavor. Luckily I made a test patty to taste and was able to adjust Here's what I ended up doing. This is per 2 pounds of turkey, which is what the recipe calls for 2 teaspoon ground sage 1 teaspoon each: dried thyme, fennel seed, chili powder, red pepper flakes, paprika, salt, pepper 1/2 tsp each: onion powder, garlic powder I also placed this in the food processor with some ice to give it that fine texture you find in commercial sausage. Rolled into 1 oz breakfast links using plastic wrap and froze raw for later use.
Very simple to make & satisfying as pork sausage without the fat.

These are very tasty! So much better than store bought and without ingredients that aren't good for anyone. I cooked one patty so I could taste it and make any adjustments needed. I did add more of the seasonings along with some thyme and oregano.... (except the salt). Yum! While forming the sausages and you don't want the meat to stick to your hands make sure your hands are wet. Keep a bowl of cool water handy.

This is a good starter recipe. As it stated, it is mild on the spices but I found it had more of a pepper kick after taste vs a breakfast sausage flavor. I deboned a turkey and ground the meat so likely was more lean than if you purchased ground burger to start.
I would have never thought that something so simple to make could have that much flavor! I’ll never buy sausage from the store again. Absolutely delicious!!!!
I love this and have already made them a couple times. Something so simple to do and turns out great. I made no changes at all.
I followed this time. It needs more spice will make the breakfast next and freeze it I am happy
GREAT!!!
Great flavor! I just added 1/4 teaspoon of dried thyme.
I make this all the time now. I'll never eat store bought or pork sausage again.
Simple and delicious! I followed the instructions exactly substituting italian seasoning for marjoram, because it's what I had. Mixed by hand and came out great!

Omg ...
My and I loved this Recipe
I used it for turkey and beef sausage.
Hopefully it freezes well

Easy to make, great flavor. I didn't have turkey handy but I used chicken thighs in a food processor, putting in the herbs and spices in the processor. I also substituted oregano for marjoram (out of marjoram) and upped the pepper flakes because I like a spicier sausage. The chicken substitution would not work with breast meat, I think, but thighs have enough fat content to add the right moisture and flavor.
Followed the directions and ingredients exactly. This is delicious!
This was super easy and WAY better than what I’ve been buying at the store!
After reading the reviews i cut back on the salt and wow it taste just like buying it from the store. great recipe that i will use over and over
I added extra red pepper, Pre-cooked and froze them in freezer bags and pulled a package at a time for easy breakfast sandwiches with healthier protein.
Very tasty!

Make sure you use finely ground turkey to get the best consistency. I also added a little Lowry’s seasoned salt to give it a more flavor. I think I’ve cured my husband from ever wanting store bought sausage again.

Delicious! I followed other reviewers suggestions to put the turkey and spices in a food processor with a few ice cubes. I have made it since without using the food processor method and it makes a huge difference in the texture. Highly recommend!

I didn't have sage or marjoram by themselves but I did have Italian seasoning that included them. Some folks said to double up on the herbs so I did 4 tsp of Italian seasoning. A few said they were too salty and I know my bf isn't a fan of too much salt so I halved that. I placed the patties in the freezer and cooked some today. I was so shocked at how juicy they were and how much they tasted like a beef pattie!! I also loved that extra kick of spiciness from the pepper flakes. My bf thought there was too much black pepper so I'll probably half that next time (Just his preference. I thought they were great.). Can't wait to make a new batch!!

This was exactly what we were looking for! We are trying to cut down on salt and processed meats.....this came out beyond expectations! Added some ice to meat mixture when in food processor, as another poster suggested. Worked great!!!
Incredibly good! I make it now for guests, for my family, for myself for lunch over a bed of lettuce, for no reason at all. DELICIOUS!
I will definitely be making this again!
I used maple syrup in place of sugar.
Great!
The first time I went by the recipe and the second time I added liquid smoke to the meat to give it that smokey taste
I've made these patty's several times. Far better than any of the commercial produced varieties I've purchased. They are great! and a healthy alternative to traditional pork sausage.

I made the recipe exactly as written. However, the next time I will add a bit more sage and hot pepper flakes. Froze some of the patties to see how they heat and taste after being frozen. It isvery good recipe. One that Iwill make again and again.

I will never buy sausage again. Used the regular ground turkey for the fat so it would not dry out, but I will use the lean ground turkey next time. I am going to make a large batch next time and freeze. I reduced the red pepper flakes and salt and increased the sage slightly (didn’t level the tsp). I also eyeballed the black pepper. It was so good.
This recipe is so good! It’ll be great for camping! Thank you!!!
I loved it and will be a main staple
I made only half the recipe. Only 1 lb of ground turkey. It was perfect. You know exactly what is in your sausage. I used all organic ingredients. If I could give it 6 stars I would!

I haven't made this yet. I am curious what a serving size is to have it equal the nutritional value. What size/weight do you need to make the patties? Any help is appreciated. I selected a 3 star rating because it sounds delicious. I will update the review after I can make it.
Flavorful, cost-effective and a good value. Added a little garlic as a personal preference. Otherwise fine.
I personally added more sage and red pepper. Delicious recipe. Thanks!

This was excellent! I have high blood pressure so I shouldn't eat store bought sausage. I didn't have marjoram or oregano in my pantry so I used rosemary. For 1 pound of ground turkey, I only used 1/4 tsp of salt (since I have to watch my sodium intake) and I used a bit more red pepper flakes and 1/4 tsp brown sugar. I followed GaryAtty's advice and put it in the food processor to make it the consistency of sausage meat. Loved this recipe!
Cut the salt by at least half. Can add some more heat if desired.
This was really good and very easy.

I used 85% lean ground turkey. This is an awesome recipe! I had no idea how easy it would be to make breakfast sausage. My family tried it right after I made it and they said it was the best sausage they ever had.
It tasted just like sausage!! Lots of flavor.
The only thing I had to do was double the spices, NOT the salt. I might even cut back on the salt a tad. But really good flavor.

These were good. I did put them through the food processor with a few small ice cubes per another reviewer, but I found the consistency very soft. I think next time I will try it without the ice cubes. I made patties today, but this would also be good browned up as crumbles for biscuits & gravy. The seasoning was great. I followed the recipe exactly (except for the ice cubes.)
I kept the recipe exactly the same except I used 1 1/2 lbs of ground turkey.
I added a 1/2 teaspoon of brown sugar

It was easy to make. I especially liked the leanness of the turkey and the spices were superb to bring out a tasty favor of sausage without a greasy mess. We will be making this recipe always as our breakfast sausage. Thank you!
Just used less salt and it was quite good.

These worked out really good for me. I added about a tablespoon of real maple syrup to the mix, after mixing in all the seasonings. Then I rolled the meat into little links (think brown-n-serve brand) and steamed them in a pan with about a half inch of boiling water, turning half way. Refrigerated, then pan-seared when I was ready to eat some. They came out really good. Thanks for this recipe!

I actually mixed this recipe with a homemade sausage recipe with pork. Same ingredients just half pork and half turkey and a tablespoon of brown sugar to sweeten the patty. Also reduced the salt by half. Next time I'll increase the red pepper flakes. Very good.

I thought these were REALLY good! I like the flavor...my only moment is not cooking it with anything, I added a little water in the skillet so the sausage wouldn't burn and dry out. I also threw a few patties in the freezer for later. I will definitely save and make this again.

Next time I will use more of all the spices. I only had one pound of ground turkey breast so I cut it in half I probably should have left it the same. It didn't have nearly enough flavor not terrible but I have 11 more patties to eat before I try to make it again unless I go ahead and use it in something else.

I have made a few attempts at making homemade sausage and it’s never tasted quite right.....until now. This is the perfect recipe. My husband did not even realize it wasn’t pork sausage. We are cutting sugar out of our diet and all the sausages in the store have sugar in them so we decided to make our own. This will be the only sausage we will eat from now on.

No changes. My family loved it just the way it is. 
Kris G.
Everyone I have made this for has liked it. It's okay as is but I usually add extra crushed red pepper. We enjoy spicy!

This is superb! I will never buy store bought sausage again! Hubby, all 4 kids and I all give it 5 stars!!! Only change I made was because I didn't have dried sage and marjoram on hand...but I did have poultry seasoning. So, I omitted the sage and marjoram and added 2 teaspoons of poultry seasoning instead and it was perfect! (Top cooked patties with some pure maple syrup for an even more decadent turkey sausage! Yummy!!!) Thanks for a new favorite recipe (already made it 3 times this week for my big family)!

I don't care for store brought Turkey breakfast sausage. So I tried this recipe and my children and I loved them. I substituted Italian seasoning as well. I even froze some of my sausages. Two thumbs up
Delicious guilt free sausage. I add a little maple syrup because I like a sweet sausage but that is the only change I make.

So I accidentally butchered this recipe! Instead of quinoa, I used rolled oats. Instead of READING the amounts, I added whatever! Ex. 1 tbsp of tomato paste turned into the entire can! Etc etc etc. Surprisingly enough though, with all the mistakes I made the loaf itself was Delicious! Husband and kid both Loved it! In the words of Bob Ross "We don't make mistakes, just happy little accidents!"
Delicious!!! I added 1/2 tsp of old bay seasoning and my goodness it was a hit!!
Needed to add extra seasoning. Kind of bland per recipe instructions.

Great recipe! I didn't have to make any changes to the ingredients. However, I did use a Ninja blender with 3 medium ice cubes to combine the meat and spices as recommended by another AllRecipes member. Blending provided an excellent consistency, and the patties stayed together without issue.

Very tasty! Made mine using ground pork as I was wanting a breakfast sausage without added sugar. Used Italian seasoning since I didn't have marjoram. Also added equal amount of oregano to increase amount of spices based on others reviews. Next time will increase red pepper flakes. This will be made again! Thank you for the recipe

Love this recipe! I also used 93% gr. turkey and I really liked the addition of the red pepper flakes. I fried a small patty first to check the seasonings - perfect! I made 12 patties yesterday but when I pulled them out this morning to package and freeze, there were only 10, hmm. Hubs just had to taste one and then another, just to make sure they were good LOL. He gave them a 10! Thank you for sharing this recipe, no more store bought in this house!

Just made this last night. Thought it had a bit too much salt, but otherwise, tasted great. Started making patties then decided to make smaller round bites that would be perfect for biscuits and gravy. I also used 1 pound of meat which I thought tasted perfect, so going to see how it'll taste with more meat but same seasonings. I'll be make this again. Thank you.

Nothing to change here! Made recipe as is and even my pork sausage loving husband really liked it! Great and healthier substitute to traditional pork based breakfast sausage. I used 93% lean ground turkey and froze the patties raw. Patties were formed roughly palm size and fairly thin. They did shrink and puff up during cooking, but were perfect portion size. Yielded about 14-15 turkey sausage patties. Excellent and quick to make on our cabin trip for quick breakfasts. Definitely will be making again instead of purchasing store bought. Thank you for sharing the recipe!

I didn't have 1/4 teaspoon marjoram so I substituted with 1/8 teaspoon thyme and 1/8 teaspoon oregano. Also, I like my breakfast sausage a little spicy so added 1/4 teaspoon ground cayenne pepper. Turned out great! I ate a couple and froze the remaining sausages. Hoping it'll taste even better after the seasoning has thoroughly been absorbed into the meat.
Lean, tasty and I will not go back to buying it already made as this taste better and is cheaper too.
These were great loved them.. I'm all about my jimmy deans pork sausage but I could do these instead. Plus they're healthier.

i halved this recipe, as not sure what the results would be. i also didn't have any marjoram :( but wanted to make these! They ARE delicious! i will definitely make these again with the addition of marjoram. i found them a tad bit dry, but hey, it's turkey and healthy, so the little bit of dryness really doesn't hamper the flavour! Thanks for a great recipe!

I made it a little spicier and cut the salt in half but I think this recipe is the BEST sausage recipe I've tried! I won't be looking for another recipe :) It was SUPER easy to make and I am so happy with the results - I've finally found a healthier non-greasy homemade sausage recipe!!

Made them ahead for the week and reheated in water on the stove (I try not to use the microwave when I don't have to). DELICIOUS!

I found it a little dry, but soooo flavorful. One of our guests isn't big on spiciness, so I (sadly) eliminated the red pepper flakes. Oh; I also reduced the salt by half. Maybe I'll add an egg for the next batch to see if that helps the dryness.
Wow, the flavour is bang on to your regular pork sausage! Thanks so much for this. As suggested by others I added some ice and an egg to everything else in a food processor.

Loved it!! I didn't have sage so I googled an appropriate sub and found that poultry seasoning would work. We don't typically eat breakfast sausages because they tend to be greasy but these taste like the real deal without the guilt. These will be on our "Breakfast for Dinner Menu" again. Thanks for sharing.

Yep! No need to buy breakfast sausage ever again. Followed exact (except I halved the recipe). 8-oz was used for my Thanksgiving stuffing, and the other 8-oz was used for sausage patties (with eggs and toast). Yep!
Just made these and I can't believe I did! They taste unreal. My husband about fell over from joy! Will put this one in my recipe book. Thank you for making me look like a rock star!

The sausage recipe I usually use is from a biscuit cook book and involves grinding your own pork and adding fat to it, although I usually use ground pork I get from the market. Even with the extra fat added, the ground pork I get is really lean, and the sausage tends to be dry. 

I had some leftover ground pork, (different store, more fatty), and was going to combine that with the ground turkey, but used all ground turkey instead when I tried this recipe. 

I have to watch my salt consumption and can't have black pepper, so I cut the salt in half, and used a lesser amount of white pepper. Instead of frying them, I baked them on a rack in the oven. It was a lot less messy. I have them individually bagged in the freezer, along with some frozen unbaked biscuits and they make a great breakfast together. Even leftover biscuits work well. I microwave the sausage for 30 seconds a side on High (700 watts) and it turns out perfectly. I really can't tell the difference between this and my pork sausage and it's not as dry and is a lot easier to make. I got 12 patties from 2 lbs. of ground turkey. This is now my go-to sausage recipe.
Thanks, cathy35
loved it. used pork loin for extra lean.

Have changed this up to be a hot Italian style for lunch sandwiches too. Added fennel, garlic, oregano and increased the red chili flakes. Flavor is very much of a good hot Italian sausage without the fat.
Wonderful flavor. I added water to the pan. Covered with a lid to keep it from drying out.

I have made this several times now and it is easily my favorite homemade sausage recipe. Sausage is very flavorful but it's too salty for my taste so I cut the salt in half. Very flavorful and the best part is I don't have to worry about preservatives and any other ingredients I cannot pronounce. I normally eat it with sourdough english muffin, fried egg and Kraft Deli cheese. Yum!

We are making significant changes to our diet and have tried several store brand turkey sausages only to find them quite bland I tried this. It tasted just like breakfast sausage (it is much more dense than pork sausage). The only addition I made was some Frank's red hot sauce, we like the hot sausage. It is a keeper and will definitely make again.

I think my search for home made turkey sausage has ended. I used Jennie-O extra lean ground turkey breast (99% lean/1% fat) in the 1.25 pound package. I made this recipe as written for 12 servings with the exception of salt. I used 2 teaspoons as recommended by LilSnoo. I also agree with her about cooking 5 minutes each side is too long. I cooked them for a little over 4 minutes until they were done. I thought the patties were very tasty. The next time I make these I will cut the salt back a little more being I thought they were still a little too salty. Thank you for sharing this recipe.

I made it as directed, and made another batch with 1 TB olive oil & 1 large egg (slightly beaten) to it. The batch with the egg & olive oil was more tender and juicier, although it was also stickier and a bit more difficult to make the patties. We fried the patties, allowed them to cool, then froze them. They were very easy to just pop into the microwave .
A decent substitute for pork sausage, it's not perfect, but much healthier. I will be using this for breakfast sandwiches from now on.
Very good! I will be making this again! Didn't have red pepper flakes so I put in a little extra ground pepper and a dash of chilli powder.

I made this exactly as the recipe calls for and it is amazing! I will definitely be making this again, and soon. This is more flavorful than truly spicy, but I will reduce the amount of red pepper for my boyfriend, who is not the fan of even slightly spicy food that I am. Thank you for the fantastic recipe. I can't imagine a crowd this would not please.

I followed the recipe pretty exactly, just added a touch more of the spices. SO easy to make! I wrapped my sausage patties individually, then put them into a ziplock freezer baggie and froze them. Just had one this morning with 1 scrambled egg, baby spinach and a piece of Provolone cheese on whole wheat toast for a healthy breakfast sammich! Delicious!
this is a good recipe! better than a lot of pork sausages I've had
To make the patty the consistency of sausage instead of hamburger the turkey and spices should be blended in a food processor with a little ice. Comes out just like commercial sausage patties.

I cut the salt in half and made these with ground chicken. Absolutely delicious! I don't feel the need to buy breakfast sausage from the store anymore. And I feel ok eating these because there are no preservatives!
I was looking for a turkey sausage recipe and I had all the ingredients I decide to give make this. Oh wow! Mouth watering and the perfect blend of seasoning!

I cut the recipe in half. I had all the spices on hand except for dried sage, so I used ground sage. 1 teaspoon dried sage equals 1/4 teaspoon ground sage. I did increase the red pepper flakes just a tad. Very tasty! I will make this from now on. One Very easy way to get the patties is to use an ice cream scoop then flatten out to a patty shape. I froze patties on a sheet then put them uncooked in a bag. I cooked up frozen patties and they were just as good as the ones I made before I froze them.

Have tried a good number of turkey sausage recipes, and hands down, this is the best! Undoubtedly, turkey sausage is a compromise (at least for me, I'm a Jimmy Dean Sausage fan) for pork sausage and the texture is different, but when it tastes this good, it's a compromise I easily can make. cathy35, thanks for a tasty and healthy breakfast today!

Wow! I expected these to be bland, but they are delicious! The spices are perfect. There's no need to buy store bought fatty sausage when this mixes up in a snap and tastes so darn good. Thanks for sharing!!!
I will never buy prepared breakfast sausage again!! My entire family loves it!

I thought this turned out good. My only changes were cutting the recipe in half as I only had 1 lb of ground turkey. I also just did a pinch of crushed red pepper flakes and at the very end added about 1 Tblsp of maple syrup. I just prefer sweeter sausage. I have found that if I use lean turkey, which I typically do, the dark and white meat mix works best for turkey sausage. It does come in lean also. For convenience sake I also made turkey crumbles and sautéed it in about a tsp of veg oil. It made about 7 servings, made as written here, at 100 calories each using 93% lean ground turkey. It worked well for breakfast burritos this morning.

I made this recipe while on a clean eating challenge, and I will probably never buy sausage again. I'm not the biggest sausage fan because of the gristle or fat that can be in it. With ground turkey, I know I'm not going to get that gross stuff. This is definitely going to be a staple in my house.
